messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:35): well now that raises an interesting point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:35): what if someone patented versioning?
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (07:37): i'm astounded nobody patented the number "3" yet (yes, the very number)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:38): the number isn't a process
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (07:45): perhaps the process by which you get to the number, via peano arithmetic
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (07:49): 4-1
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (07:51): wonders what peano arithmetic might be
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (07:51): but, AFAIK, you can't patent mathematical equations
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (07:52): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peano_axioms
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (07:52): "S(S(1))"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:07): Can someone tell Mike Schinkel how Thunderbird works?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:08): If I remember correctly it certainly supports text plain editing of e-mails.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:08): FYI: http://www.w3.org/mid/op.tqwwnwan64w2qv@id-c0020 (presentation on HTML5 I gave today at QUT)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:14): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 - was the presentation well-received? how many people there?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:14): about 50 or so, I believe they liked it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:15): did you get some good questions?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:15): some people wondered if providing specific elements was going to scale
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:15): like with <progress> and <meter>
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:16): so what was your response to that?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:16): my response was that those are pretty fundamental features for most operating systems and applications
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:17): and that we're only adding features with very good use cases
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:18): and also that if they had a better way of doing it they should certainly join!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:19): anyway, perhaps a good reason why it might help to have the use cases behind those elements (and other parts of the spec) better documented
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:19): also how it relates to Web 2.0 and Ajax
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:20): to which I replies that we're basically trying to improve upon that movement
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:20): s/replies/replied/
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:20): "evolving the web"

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:30): I'm thinking that for presentations like this, it'd also be useful to have a record of the Q&A. Could use RRSagent for that, use scribe formatter thingy to generate HTML-formatted record of it as we do for WG meetings.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:31): then post URI to www-archive
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:32): yeah, maybe
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:32): no RRSAgent where I gave it though
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:36): hands 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 a hot cup of black coffee
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (08:37): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: probably not a good idea this late at night

6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (08:39): i wish i understood better this "pixel perfect" thread/bussiness. is that what would be needed to be able to print html decentrly? /to be more specific, what would be needed to finally get rid of pdf once and for all)
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (08:39): and if this is so...what's needed in thml itself? isn't it a css matter?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:42): It's not for <canvas>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:42): It's for the other stuff, although HTML elements might have some default CSS applied to it
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:43): Have some default CSS applied to it for certain media
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (08:43): default rendering should be specified to some extent for interop
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (08:44): it's hard to walk the line between over- and under-specifying there
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:44): Great extent probably
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:44): It's amazing what people rely on

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (08:44): well, like I said, I don't think you want to standardize things like how to rasterize glyphs, what fonts must be available, whether to use bilinear or bicubic scaling for scaled images, etc
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (08:45): I also don't want to rule out the various hacks that mobile browsers do to fit text content to a small screen
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (08:50): what would take to completely get rid of pdf? to end up with just one content authoring language, html?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:52): I think dhyatt's description of <canvas> as "just a dynamic image" is apt.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:53): I used that one
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (08:53): in my pres

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:03): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 - please remind me: Was there ever discussion about adding an unnumbered <h> element to the Web Apps 1.0 spec? (instead of using h1-h6)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (09:05): yes
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (09:05): the reason it's not there is for backcompat
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:06): I see
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:07): it is there
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:07): it's just called <h1>
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (09:07): fair enough

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:15): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e - regarding the default rendering rules (as mentioned in 1.1 Scope), is the intention for that to be a comprehensive set of rules or just for new elements?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:16): the former

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:18): What are intended processing expectations for h1 as a child of <section>? The UA renders it in an appropriate font size based on the level of section nesting?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:19): that's one possibility
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:19): we haven't looked at how feasible it is to do that given the backwards compatibility constraints yet
